text:
Brexit has added an 'extra layer of uncertainty to our world' says Nicky Morgan By danjmartin   2 COMMENTS SHARES Brexit has added an 'extra layer of uncertainty to our world' says Nicky Morgan   Comments (2) 
MPs are set to vote tonight on triggering Britain's exit from the European Union after two days of debate in Parliament. 
Loughborough Conservative member Nicky Morgan was one of a large number of MPs to contribute to the discussion today. 
She expressed concerns about Brexit, but said she accepted the democratic vote expressed in the June referendum. 
The MP began by paying tribute to the "wonderful speech" delivered by Tory colleague Ken Clarke on Tuesday. In his speech, Mr Clarke, who represents Rushcliffe, over the border from Mrs Morgan's own constituency, compared post-Brexit trade hopes to Alice in Wonderland. 
Mrs Morgan said: "Boy, does he show us how it's all done. I campaigned, like others on this side, for remain, but I accept the democratic vote and we should allow the Article 50 notice to be triggered. 
"I do agree with those who say if we do not do that, a crisis in our democracy, which a defeat for this bill would lead to, helps no one." 
However she added: "Leaving must not undermine our economy. It must not unduly affect the jobs and the household finances and financial security of our constituents 
"Leaving must not undermine our constitution. That was tested in the courts and I welcome the decision of the high court, which was upheld by the supreme court. 
"Finally, it must not undermine our values as a country. I have to be honest - never in my adult life have I felt so concerned about the stability and the state of the world in which we live. 
"I have to say I think, with the Brexit vote, we have added an extra layer of uncertainty to our world." 
Read more: 'Shocking' figures show number of people in Leicester travelling by bus has slumped in last 7 years 
Some Labour MPs and shadow ministers have said they would not follow leader Jeremy Corbyn's three line whip and support the bill tonight. 
A spokesman for shadow health secretary and Leicester South MP Jon Ashworth said he would support the bill despite having campaigned to remain in the EU. 
A spokesman for Labour Leicester West MP Liz Kendall said she would support the bill too. 
Keith Vaz's office did not respond to a Mercury inquiry about how he would vote. 
All the county's Tory MPs are expected to back the Brexit Bill as it passes.
